title: 106_s1117
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Corinth Battlefield Preservation Act of 2000" and includes findings and purposes. Congress finds that in 1996, the establishment of a center was authorized to interpret the Siege and Battle of Corinth and enhance public understanding of the Civil War in Corinth, Mississippi. The Corinth Battlefield was identified as a priority 1 battlefield by the Civil War Sites Advisory Commission. The Act aims to establish the Corinth Unit of the Shiloh National Military Park in Corinth, Mississippi, and Tennessee. It directs the Secretary of the Interior to manage, protect, and interpret resources related to the Civil War Siege and Battle of Corinth. Mississippi and Tennessee have the authority to preserve historic sites associated with the Civil War. The Act establishes the Corinth Unit of the Shiloh National Military Park in Corinth, Mississippi, and Tennessee. It directs the Secretary of the Interior to manage, protect, and interpret resources related to the Civil War Siege and Battle of Corinth, in cooperation with various entities. Additionally, a special resource study will identify other Civil War sites in the area for potential inclusion in the National Park System. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Map - "Park Boundary-Corinth Unit" map, dated October 1998.
(2) Park - Shiloh National Military Park.
(3) Secretary - Secretary of the Interior.
(4) Unit - Corinth Unit of Shiloh National Military Park.

SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF UNIT. The Corinth Unit of the Shiloh National Military Park is established in Mississippi and Tennessee, comprising approximately 20 acres of land. Additional suitable land may be included based on ownership and historical significance. A map of the Unit is available for public inspection. Land acquisition is addressed in the following section. The Secretary can acquire land within the Park boundary through donation, purchase with funds, or exchange. Land can only be donated by specific entities. Park management and administration are addressed in the following section. The Secretary administers the Unit in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Act and the Historic Sites Act. Duties include commemorating and interpreting the Siege and Battle of Corinth and other Civil War actions in the area. The Secretary administers the Unit in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Act and the Historic Sites Act, to commemorate and interpret the Siege and Battle of Corinth and other Civil War actions in the area. This includes identifying and preserving surviving features from the Civil War era, such as the role of railroads, the Corinth contraband camp, and the development of field fortifications as a tactic of war through cooperative agreements with entities in the public and private sectors. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to entities engaged in protecting historically significant Civil War resources in the area around Corinth, including states, governmental entities, nonprofit organizations, and private property owners. The Secretary can offer technical assistance to protect Civil War resources in Corinth area for states, governmental entities, nonprofit organizations, and private property owners. The Secretary is not authorized to own or manage resources outside the designated Unit. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF SPECIAL RESOURCE STUDY. The Secretary will conduct a special resource study of land in and around Corinth, Mississippi, and nearby areas in Tennessee related to the Civil War Siege and Battle of Corinth in 1862. The study will identify resources and historic themes associated with the campaign. The special resource study will identify historic themes related to the Civil War Siege and Battle of Corinth in 1862, including the relationship to other operations in the western theater of the Civil War in Corinth and Tennessee. It will also explore alternatives for preserving Civil War era features, potential partners to support the Secretary in carrying out the study, and military and civilian themes such as the role of the railroad, the Corinth contraband camp, and field fortifications. The Secretary will conduct a special resource study on the Civil War Siege and Battle of Corinth in 1862, identifying historic themes and alternatives for preservation. The study will include cost estimates for acquisition, development, interpretation, operation, and maintenance. A report will be submitted to the Senate and House Committees within 1 year and 180 days of funds availability. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the construction of an interpretive center under the Omnibus Parks and Public Lands Management Act of 1996.
